channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Top Indian Candidate, Believed a Bachelor, Admits to Being Married
item.description: Narendra Modi, of the Bharatiya Janata Party, had said his being single would be an advantage as prime minister, but now admits in an election filing to having a wife.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Greece Trumpets Return to International Bond Market
item.description: After investors flocked to its five-year debt offering, Athens said it was a sign that the country was succeeding in turning its economy around.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Finance Minister Yannis Stournaras described the move as “a catalytic undertaking,” adding that Greece had made “the biggest fiscal adjustment ever recorded since World War II.”

item.title: In Eastern Ukraine, a One-Building, Pro-Russia Realm Persists Despite Criticism
item.description: A group of protesters who have seized the government headquarters in Donetsk, Ukraine, was urged by local politicians to give up and hand over their weapons.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A version of the flag of the Donetsk People’s Republic hung in an occupied government building.

item.title: India Ink: All Eyes on Delhi As It Goes To Vote
item.description: The three-way race for the capital’s seven parliamentary seats could be a bellwether of the national elections.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A woman cast her vote with her child during parliamentary elections on Thursday in New Delhi.

item.title: India Ink: How the Aam Aadmi Party Lost Its Way
item.description: After a surprising victory in the Delhi State elections, a series of strategic mistakes have arrested what at one point seemed the party’s irresistible momentum.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, center, Aam Aadmi Party's official candidate from the Varanasi parliamentary constituency, with supporters on the banks of River Ganges in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, on March 25.

item.title: In Mongolia, Hagel Gets a Horse, Just for a Bit
item.description: A traditional gift from Mongolia to American officials typically does not make its way back to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Mongolia’s minister of defense, Bat-Erdene Dashdemberel, left, presented U.S. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel with a horse as a gift on Thursday.

item.title: Prosecutor Describes Pistorius as a Self-Centered Bully
item.description: In the closely-watched murder trial in the South African capital, Oscar Pistorius faced interrogation by a relentless prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arrives at court on Thursday in Pretoria.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Seeking More From Chinese Films
item.description: A jury at the China Film Directors’ Guild awards refused to award the two top prizes — for film and director of the year — saying that Chinese films need to meet “a higher standard.”
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The actress Zhao Tao in a scene from Jia Zhangke's film "A Touch of Sin," which has been barred from release in China.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Students End Occupation of Taiwan’s Legislature
item.description: Their departure concludes the most dramatic confrontation over ratification of a trade agreement with China.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Student protesters carrying the sunflowers that symbolize their movement for government transparency walked out of the legislature building after they ended their occupation.

item.title: Bomb Explodes Outside Greek Central Bank
item.description: No one was hurt in the explosion in Athens, which took place hours before Greece was to start issuing long-term bonds for the first time since 2010.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Police gathered evidence at the site of an explosion in Athens on Thursday.

item.title: Possible Signal Detected in Search for Malaysia Air Jet
item.description: Acoustic data would have to be analyzed further but the source appeared to be man-made, the Australian authorities conducting the search said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A version of this torpedo-like, sonar-equipped vehicle, made by Bluefin Robotics, of Quincy, Mass., may be used to search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, if signals turn out to be authentic.

item.title: India Ink: Setting Up an Election in the World’s Largest Democracy
item.description: The chief electoral officer in Uttar Pradesh, India’s most populous state, said the enormous task is “not an ordinary job, but a mission.”
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Raj Singh, right, sewing tents for the meeting of polling officials at Victoria Park in Meerut, Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: European Union Debates Initiative on Embryo Protection
item.description: A hearing was held on a petition bearing 1.8 million signatures that would ban the use of European funds for activities such as stem-cell research.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: French Premier Presents New Brand of Socialism
item.description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls is more centrist on social issues, more conservative economically and more combative than the man who appointed him, President François Hollande.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Early Count in Indonesia Favors Largest Opposition Party
item.description: The biggest prize in Wednesday’s balloting is the House of Representatives, where the results will bear directly on the presidential election in July.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: A man cast his ballot in Banten Province on Wednesday.

item.title: Putin Warns of Restricting Natural Gas Supply to Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin and other senior Russian officials also reiterated the Kremlin’s contention that Ukraine owes Russia more than $16 billion in unpaid gas bills and other debts.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 10
item.description: A roundup of the top election-related news for Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Officials checked electronic voting machines before they were sent to polling stations in New Delhi.

item.title: Flight Search Brings Satellite Company Unaccustomed Fame
item.description: Inmarsat, the company keeping tabs on the flow of information about Flight 370, has found itself thrust, uncomfortably, into the spotlight.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Japan Pushes Plan to Stockpile Plutonium, Despite Proliferation Risks
item.description: Japan is set to push ahead with a program that would produce new stockpiles of weapon-grade plutonium, creating a proliferation risk for decades to come.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: The lightly guarded Rokkasho Reprocessing Plant, where Japan stores much of its plutonium.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Can China Cast Off Despotism?
item.description: A relentless parade of political trials raises a giant question: As China revels in its growing power, is it able or willing to discard ancient habits?
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Russia Didn’t Share All Details on Boston Bombing Suspect, Report Says
item.description: Two years before the bombings, Russia declined to give the F.B.I. information that most likely would have prompted deeper scrutiny of Tamerlan Tsarnaev, an inspector general’s review said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Julia Malakie/The Sun of Lowell, via Associated Press

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Deadly Car Bomb Blasts Hit Homs
item.description: Two car bombs exploded minutes apart near a shop in the central Syrian city of Homs on Wednesday, killing at least 25 people, state news media and an antigovernment monitoring group reported.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: After Optimism of More Pings, Reality of Long Jet Search Settles In
item.description: Specialists in ocean exploration and recovery cautioned that a successful identification of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370’s wreckage might take weeks or months.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:description: A version of this torpedo-like, sonar-equipped vehicle, made by Bluefin Robotics, of Quincy, Mass., may be used to search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, if signals turn out to be authentic.

item.title: Mechanics of the Plane Search, Explained
item.description: How the multinational team off the coast of Australia is continuing the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Envoy Urges Support for Peacekeeping Troops
item.description: Samantha Power, the American ambassador to the United Nations, on Wednesday urged more support for existing African and French troops in the Central African Republic on the eve of a United Nations vote to create a peacekeeping mission.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Samantha Power, the American ambassador to the United Nations, in March.
